The Museum of Contemporary Art (MoCA) in Los Angeles has appointed Lorraine Oxtoby as the next director of its contemporary art museum. She will be responsible for guiding the museum through the construction of its new building, which will open to the public in 2021, and will take up the post on October 6.“I’ve been a huge supporter of the museum,” Oxtoby said. “Over the past ten years, I have worked to make MoCA an exciting destination for everyone, attracting new audiences to the institution by bringing them to the museum through experiences that were new and challenging, and by working with some of the most talented and thoughtful people in the world, including Jon Landau, Lisa Loeb, Sarah Lyon, and Frances Stark. I’m excited to welcome MoCA’s diverse audiences and audiences that have come to love the institution.”Prior to joining the museum, Oxtoby served as director of the John Simon Guggenheim Foundation’s contemporary art museum here, which she helmed from 2006 to 2013. The UES Art Story, a new collaboration between New York University and the New Museum, has created more than 1,500 full-time and part-time positions across its two museums. The institution says that the initiative, “provides an opportunity for artists to collaborate and work across disciplines, making the UES Art Story a viable option for students interested in becoming involved in the arts.”The program, funded by the $1.2 billion U.S. Conference of Mayors, was launched with $300,000 from the New Museum’s $1 billion plan for revitalization, and is being spearheaded by William Schaeffer, director of the New Museum; Berit Stahl, director of the UES Art Story; and Elissa Farquharson, chair of the UES Art Story’s board of trustees.
